articles.headline: Nikki Haley, South Carolina Governor, Calls for Removal of Confederate Battle Flag
articles.snippet: Gov. Nikki Haley’s call to remove the flag from Capitol grounds came in the wake of the killing of nine people in a Charleston church.
articles.abstract: Gov. Nikki Haley’s call to remove the flag from Capitol grounds came in the wake of the killing of nine people in a Charleston church.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Gov. Nikki R. Haley called on Monday for South Carolina to do what just a week ago seemed politically impossible — remove the Confederate battle flag from its perch in front of the State House building here. She argued that a symbol long revered by many Southerners was for some, after the church massacre in Charleston, a “deeply offensive symbol of a brutally offensive past.”
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Richard Fausset and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Cancer Doctors Offer Way to Compare Medicines, Including by Cost
articles.snippet: Alarmed by soaring prices for cancer drugs, the leading American oncology society has devised a “value framework” to evaluate treatments by effectiveness, side effects and cost.
articles.abstract: Alarmed by soaring prices for cancer drugs, the leading American oncology society has devised a “value framework” to evaluate treatments by effectiveness, side effects and cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by the rapid escalation in the price of cancer drugs, the nation’s leading oncology society unveiled on Monday a new way for doctors and patients to evaluate different treatments — one that pointedly includes a medicine’s cost as well as its effectiveness and side effects.

articles.headline: Takata Is Said to Have Stopped Safety Audits as Cost-Saving Move
articles.snippet: Internal company emails said that the audits were halted in 2009, a committee report said, a year after Honda had begun a recall to replace defective airbags.
articles.abstract: Internal company emails said that the audits were halted in 2009, a committee report said, a year after Honda had begun a recall to replace defective airbags.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the middle of what would become the largest automotive recall in American history, the Japanese airbag manufacturer Takata halted global safety audits to save money, according to internal company emails cited in a report published on Monday by a Senate committee.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: AirAsia Faces Red Tape and Tough Competition in India
articles.snippet: AirAsia has exported its low-cost model to India, hoping to catch its hundreds of millions in first-time fliers. The move has proven harder than expected.
articles.abstract: AirAsia has exported its low-cost model to India, hoping to catch its hundreds of millions in first-time fliers. The move has proven harder than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: DELHI — When the fast-growing Malaysian carrier AirAsia wanted to expand, India looked like the ideal frontier.

articles.headline: With a Tap of Taylor Swift’s Fingers, Apple Retreated
articles.snippet: Ms. Swift’s victory in a one-day battle against Apple this week showed she has a rare power to influence the music business.
articles.abstract: Ms. Swift’s victory in a one-day battle against Apple this week showed she has a rare power to influence the music business.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an age of depressed record sales, her albums sell by the millions. Her tours fill arenas around the world. And a complimentary tweet to her nearly 60 million followers can help kick-start another singer’s career.

articles.headline: The Loneliness of the Short-Seller
articles.snippet: Six years into a bull market run, with stocks smashing one record after another, the naysayers known as short-sellers have all but lost their voice.
articles.abstract: Six years into a bull market run, with stocks smashing one record after another, the naysayers known as short-sellers have all but lost their voice.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some, they are the scourge of Wall Street. Yet short-sellers — investors who stake bets against stocks — are often the first to sound the alarm on a market’s froth or a company’s fraud.

articles.headline: As South Sudan Crisis Worsens, ‘There Is No More Country’
articles.snippet: In the world’s newest nation, the fighting, atrocities and hunger have increased, with no end in sight to the warring leaders’ power struggle.
articles.abstract: In the world’s newest nation, the fighting, atrocities and hunger have increased, with no end in sight to the warring leaders’ power struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: MALAKAL, South Sudan — In places where the fighting is fiercest, no one is even attempting to count the dead.

articles.headline: Council of Conservative Citizens Promotes White Primacy, and G.O.P. Ties
articles.snippet: The massacre in Charleston, S.C., has propelled the organization back onto the national stage and embroiled the Republican Party in new questions about its ties to the group.
articles.abstract: The massacre in Charleston, S.C., has propelled the organization back onto the national stage and embroiled the Republican Party in new questions about its ties to the group.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Council of Conservative Citizens opposes “all efforts to mix the races,” and believes “that the American people and government should remain European in their composition and character.” It would severely restrict immigration, abolish affirmative action and dismantle the “imperial judiciary” that produced, among other rulings, the 1954 Supreme Court decision that integrated American education.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Health Care Law Spurs Merger Talks for Insurers
articles.snippet: All the deal-making in the health care industry is largely the result of the Affordable Care Act, which in effect caps hospitals’ and insurers’ profits.
articles.abstract: All the deal-making in the health care industry is largely the result of the Affordable Care Act, which in effect caps hospitals’ and insurers’ profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama signed the Affordable Care Act more than five years ago. At the time, members of the health care industry — hospitals, doctors and insurers — were anxious about what it would do to the business. Everyone had an opinion, but nobody knew for sure.

articles.headline: Trade Accord, Once Blocked, Nears Passage
articles.snippet: President Obama’s ambitious trade push is back on track, after several near-death moments, in large measure because top Republicans stood by him.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s ambitious trade push is back on track, after several near-death moments, in large measure because top Republicans stood by him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s ambitious trade push is back on track, after several near-death moments, in large measure because top Republicans stood by him.

articles.headline: NATO Refocuses on the Kremlin, Its Original Foe
articles.snippet: Military training exercises this month in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, underline the seismic shift for an alliance that had been focused on threats far beyond its borders.
articles.abstract: Military training exercises this month in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, underline the seismic shift for an alliance that had been focused on threats far beyond its borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP ADAZI, Latvia — After years of facing threats far beyond its borders, NATO is now reinvigorating plans to confront a much larger and more aggressive threat from its past: Moscow.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Calls to Drop Confederate Emblems Spread Nationwide
articles.snippet: Scattered calls to remove the Confederate battle flag from a single state capitol have intensified with striking speed and scope into an emotional, nationwide movement.
articles.abstract: Scattered calls to remove the Confederate battle flag from a single state capitol have intensified with striking speed and scope into an emotional, nationwide movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — What began as scattered calls for removing the Confederate battle flag from a single state capitol intensified with striking speed and scope on Tuesday into an emotional, nationwide movement to strip symbols of the Confederacy from public parks and buildings, license plates, Internet shopping sites and retail stores.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Monica Davey and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Lawmakers Spread Anger in Recalls Over Airbags
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has been under scrutiny after extensive recalls of faulty Takata airbags and G.M. switches.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has been under scrutiny after extensive recalls of faulty Takata airbags and G.M. switches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Takata, the Japanese auto supplier, returned to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to try to alleviate fears about its airbags that have killed at least eight people and injured more than 100 others.
